awd_titl_txt: DMREF: High Throughput Design of Metallic Glasses with Physically Motivated Descriptors
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: Silica-based glasses are familiar to most of us from our experiences with everything from windows to wineglasses. However, when cooled quickly enough, some metal alloys can also form a glassy state. Metallic glasses have attractive properties such as high elastic modulus, excellent strength, good biocompatibility, and the ability to be processed like plastics. Applications include packaging, arterial stents, water purification, and Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems gears and springs. The slowest cooling rate that still forms a glass is called the critical cooling rate. Although many metals can form a glass, only a rare set of alloys have slow enough critical cooling rate that they can form a significant bulk volume of glassy material, and these alloys are said to have good glass forming ability. Despite the importance of these materials and years of research, there are still no rigorous, consistent, and quantitative rules to predict the actual glass forming ability of a metallic alloy system. To solve this problem, this project will develop an extensible materials informatics framework for predicting the glass-forming ability of metal alloys, and then apply that framework to develop aluminum- and magnesium-based alloys with improved glass forming ability.

Technical description: In order to discover new aluminum- and magnesium-based bulk metallic glasses with superior glass-forming ability, the team will execute a dual-loop iterative materials design approach. A rapid materials design loop will provide high-throughput materials discovery by integrating experimental and simulated data with machine learning methods. An unprecedented body of experimental data on glass forming ability and basic mechanical properties will be generated by combinatorial 3D printing synthesis, followed by rapid optical, microscopy, thermal, and nanomechanical characterization. A similarly unique database of liquid and glass thermodynamic, kinetic, and structural properties will be determined by automated, high-throughput ab initio molecular dynamics. Machine-learning methods, trained on the data and physically motivated descriptors from existing experiments and the ab initio molecular dynamics simulation, will search a space of up to hundreds of thousands of potential alloys for the most promising candidates, which will then be synthesized, characterized and used to refine the models. Slower descriptor design loop studies will study select alloys in detail with fluctuation electron microscopy and extensive simulations to develop improved descriptors, which will then be incorporated into the rapid materials design loop and further validated by their predictive ability. This work will produce the first set of large-scale databases with both true measures of glass forming ability and extensive thermophysical data from simulations, and integrate them to generate physical descriptor driven machine-learning models for iterative new metallic glass search and discovery. The PIs also plan to release the Materials Simulation Toolkit - Machine Learning (MASTML) as open source and build a user community around the language by ensuring that interested researchers are able to contribute to the MASTML codebase. This will allow a wider growth of the project. This aspect is of special interest to the software cluster in the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure, which has provided co-funding for this award.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Traditional metal alloys form crystal structures, with small arrangements of typically just few atoms repeated periodically in space, which give rise to many of the common characteristics we associate with metals. However, if we cool a molten metal quickly enough it is possible to prevent crystals from forming and the atoms get stuck in structures similar to the disordered liquid-like arrangement. These disordered arrangements are similar to the way atoms are organized in traditional glass, like that used in windows, and we refer to metals in this structure as metallic glasses. Because of the different arrangement of atoms in metallic glasses they have attractive properties such as high elastic modulus, excellent strength, good biocompatibility, and the ability to be processed like plastics. Current applications include packaging, arterial stents, water purification, and Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems gears and springs. One of the limitations of metallic glasses is that it is rare that a specific composition of elements will have the ability to form a glassy structure under experimental cooling conditions. The ability for each composition to form a metallic glass can be quantified by experimentally cooling the liquid metal down at different cooling rates and finding slowest cooling rate before crystals start to form. This rate is referred to as the critical cooling rate of the composition, and compositions that can be made into metallic glasses with low critical cooling rates are referred to as having good glass forming ability. The goal of this project is to improve our ability to predict the glass forming ability of new alloys by combining machine learning modeling with high-throughput experimentation. Better prediction will enable us to develop new metallic glasses more quickly and more cheaply.

The machine learning efforts focused on two core ideas. First, expanding the range of accessible features which are used as inputs to the models. And second, expanding existing databases of relevant metallic glass properties. We proposed new computable features that can be obtained from computer simulations and don’t require synthesis of the metallic glasses, like some previous features. Expanding databases of metallic glasses improved the machine learning models by expanding the range of applicability of the models by allowing the models to train on >5,000 glass forming compositions. Machine learning predictions were then made across a wide range of potential metallic glass compositions and a candidate system in the Mg-Ni-Y ternary was selected to investigate.

To experimentally test predictions made by the machine learning models, we had a goal of enabling high throughput synthesis of metal alloys. To achieve this high-throughput synthesis methods were developed to utilize the LENS additive manufacturing system to synthesize metallic glasses. Initial tests were done on previous well-known Mg-based metallic alloys to demonstrate the ability to obtain glassy structures and then the new Mg-Ni-Y system was explored as well. Along with the high-throughput synthesis of metal alloys, corresponding high-throughput characterization techniques were developed to identify metallic glasses from the hundreds of samples generated. These combined rapid machine learning predictions and synthesis are summarized in Figure 1, which demonstrates the ability to predict across an entire system and perform targeted synthesis on the areas with the best predicted glass forming ability.

Work was also done to extend our machine learning and experimental approaches from glass forming ability to consider the mechanical properties of synthesized metallic glasses. High throughput nano-indentation techniques were used to rapidly investigate mechanical properties on a large library of LENS printed Fe-Cr-Mn-Ni single phase alloys. This enabled us to visualize the mechanical properties over a large composition space to easily observe trends and identify regions of compositions with higher strength.


Last Modified: 01/30/2023
Modified by: Dane Morgan

Image
  • Figure 1. Machine learning predicted critical cooling rate and measured glass forming ability in Mg-Ni-Y. Red point represents first discovery of a bulk metallic glass in this system. Purple represents machine learning prediction of optimal GFA (low values from Rc) at nearby compositions.
    Dane Morgan
    Creative Commons
    Dane Morgan
    Mg-Ni-Y Ternary Predictions
